snippet: The so-called rebates that stock exchanges pay Wall Street firms could give those firms an incentive to profit at the expense of investors, experts find.
abstract: Former regulators find so-called rebates that stock exchanges pay Wall Street firms to send them business could give those firms an incentive to profit at the expense of investors; study by Woodbine Associates, which uses industry data, says rebates could be costing mutual funds, pension funds and ordinary investors as much as $5 billion a year.
lead_paragraph: The so-called rebates that stock exchanges pay Wall Street firms could give those firms an incentive to profit at the expense of investors, experts find.

headline.seo: Rebates to Brokers Are Seen As a Conflict of Interest
headline.main: Study Says Broker Rebates Cost Investors Billions
headline.print_headline: Study Says Broker Rebates Cost Investors Billions
